user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following get_rq_dauth_algo code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 21.17.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of get_rq_dauth_algo.
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3
get_rq_dauth_algo (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const algo_param)
{
  if (NULL == algo_param->value.str)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5; /* Assume MD5 by default */

  if (algo_param->quoted)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))

      /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

    /* No known algorithm has been detected */
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
  }
  /* The algorithm value is not quoted */
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

  /* No known algorithm has been detected */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The macro call passes a string literal (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN => "SHA-256-sess") as the first argument and algo_param->value.len as the comparison length. If the underlying MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ is implemented using a string.h routine that reads up to the supplied length (e.g. strncasecmp/strncmp(token, buf, n)), and algo_param->value.len is greater than the length of the literal (for example algo_param->value.len == 20 while the literal length is 12), the string-h.c function will attempt to read beyond the bounds of the literal object, causing undefined behavior. Thus Rule 21.17 can be violated by this fragment.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_rq_dauth_algo:
#define _MHD_MD5_TOKEN "MD5"
...
#define _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN "SHA-256"
...
#define _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN "SHA-512-256"
...
#define _MHD_SESS_TOKEN "-sess"
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: Agent A is correct: the code can violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The calls use macros like MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_/_quoted_... with a string-literal token as one argument and algo_param->value.len as the length. If the underlying implementation of those helpers uses a <string.h> routine that reads a fixed number of bytes (for example memcmp(token, buf, n) or any routine that unconditionally reads n bytes from each pointer), and algo_param->value.len is greater than the size of the string-literal object (including its terminating NUL), the library routine will read beyond the bounds of the literal object — undefined behavior and a direct breach of Rule 21.17. Even though some implementations of strncmp/strncasecmp stop at a NUL and therefore wouldn’t read past the terminator, you cannot rely on that for all routines (e.g. memcmp) nor on unspecified helper implementations. Without a guarantee that the comparison helper limits reads to the actual token object size (or uses the token length rather than algo_param->value.len), the use is potentially out-of-bounds and non‑compliant with Rule 21.17.
